page.title: 13Farming Changes At Mulben
page.content: When farmers in this area began to grow wheat and barley in preference to oats, the Agricultural Colleges and Research Units experimented with different varieties of seeds suitable for sowing in the cold, wet climate of the North of Scotland. Now all the farmers grow winter wheat. The fields are ploughed in Autumn and the seed is sown. It begins to germinate, and is hardy enough to withstand the cold of Winter. When Spring comes and growth returns, the winter wheat grows and ripens over the Summer. It is ready for harvesting in August. Farmers here, like to have their winter wheat harvested before the Keith Show Day which is on the second Tuesday of August. After harvesting, a field is ploughed, ready for sowing the next year's crop of winter wheat. This can all happen on the same day.
